translated: New Commentary on the Flower Ornament Scripture, Scroll 6
Composed by Elder Li Tongxuan

The bodhisattvas of the first ground have many hundreds of Dharma gates, transforming many hundreds of buddha-realms. The bodhisattvas of the second ground have many thousands of Dharma gates, transforming many thousands of buddha-realms. This is different from the limited teachings of the provisional teachings, as the number of dharmas mutually penetrate each other as before.

Moreover, it is like a person using their finger to draw hundreds of thousands of dust motes in the sky, and then using their hand to remove them all, yet the space in the sky neither increases nor decreases.
Because of conceptual measurement, one sees the number of dust motes in the sky as increasing and decreasing.
This is also so. The increase and decrease of the Dharma gates established by the bodhisattvas in the various grounds is also like this.
It is for the sake of perfecting sentient beings that they are caused to progress in cultivation. If they were all equal, there would be no mind to progress.
Ordinary beings have no mind to progress in cultivation. Whether one gives rise to the mind to cultivate or not, only then does one know that the myriad dharmas are without cultivation.

However, in the real teaching, bodhisattvas attain all at once, in accordance with the principle that there is no sequence in the essence of phenomena. It is like the lights and shadows in the emperor's net, mutually penetrating and interpenetrating, without any sequence.
It is also like hundreds of thousands of precious mirrors reflecting a wonderful image, with the reflections of each mirror interpenetrating and the colors and forms being the same.
Just as in the stage of buddhahood, the bodhisattvas arise from the fundamental wisdom of the Dharma body based on their nature, and initially realize the mind within the ten abodes.
All the Dharma gates and realms are based on the original essence, because the essence and function are completely included and penetrate through.
They are still equal to the nature, because the time is the same.
There cannot be any other dharmas that are not equal.

It is different from the provisional teachings where the emotional hindrances of sentient beings have not yet been eliminated. Those below the ninth ground have not yet seen the buddha-nature, and the stages they establish all have boundaries that can be attained, because they have not yet seen the buddha-nature and have only the shadow of the provisional true suchness.
Therefore, the sutra says, The distinctions of the ten grounds are like bird tracks in the sky.
The Dharma gates of the stages and grounds are provisionally established with increases and decreases, in order to follow the dispositions of sentient beings.
For those who realize the truth, the conventional and the real are simply the real, because one truth is all truths, so there are no provisional dharmas at all.
One should not view increases and decreases in this perfect teaching, the same as in the gradual [approach].

All the multitudes of bodhisattvas and devas, dragons, spirits, etc. in this sutra are the multitudes of bodhisattvas in the ocean of the Buddha's fruition stage, not ordinary beings. It is to cause those who wish to enter to be the same as the sages, clarifying that Vairocana's realm of embracing and transforming is as pervasive as sentient beings.
They are all the multitudes in the Buddha's fruition stage, because they are the host and companions of the transformative methods.
In this way, the multitudes in the fruition stage gather together to form the Dharma, demonstrating and awakening sentient beings.

After completing the Dharma, they entered the Chapter on the Dharma Realm. MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«, with this fruition-based Dharma door, left the Jeta Grove and went east, wishing to go to the city of awakening to benefit others.

To the east of the city of awakening, MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« met Sudhana and sought out various friends, perfecting the fruition of one lifetime.

Five hundred upÄsakas, five hundred upÄsikÄs, five hundred young men, and five hundred young women were all like Sudhana. The sÅ«tra text cannot list them all one by one. They all gathered together in the same way.
If there is no affinity, they will not hear it at all. It is like the arhat bhiká¹£us in the Jeta Grove who gathered together but did not hear or see the TathÄgata expound this Flower Ornament Sutra.

Therefore, the sÅ«tra says, This sÅ«tra does not fall into the hands of other sentient beings.
Those who can deeply believe in it are those whose feelings surpass those of the provisional learners of the three vehicles, let alone those who are able to realize it.

Therefore, in the Chapter on the Foremost of Worthies of this sutra, it says, Among the multitudes of living beings in all worlds, few aspire to the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle, those who aspire to the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle are even fewer, and those who aspire to the Great Vehicle are extremely rare.

Therefore, one should know that in the assembly of the ocean-like congregation, there were no ordinary people among humans, but only bodhisattvas of the fruition stage of the buddhas gathered, forming their teaching.

The five assemblies such as Sudhana collectively represent those who truly attain this Dharma. The other meanings are as explained above.

Such an assembly of comers is purely composed of bodhisattvas in the stage of fruition, manifesting the complete fruition virtues and superior capacities. There is no assembly of bodhisattvas of provisional teachings, disciples of the two vehicles, or ordinary beings of the five turbidities coming to this assembly.
Bodhisattvas of provisional teachings, up to the ninth stage, are not included in this assembly, let alone ordinary beings.
Why is this so?
It is because they practice the six perfections.

Although there are those who practice the ten perfections, because they attain the fruition of enlightenment in three incalculable eons, it is different from this teaching where one instant is all instants, and therefore not included in the realm of sentient beings.

Leaving the Jeta Grove, Manjushri went east, and six thousand bhikshus generated the resolve on the road. This shows that it is permitted for shravakas to also have the supreme vessel, and they are able to enter this supreme vehicle.

Moreover, those six thousand bhikshus had all newly left the household life under Shariputra, and had not yet delighted in the lesser fruition. Because their vessels were sharp, they were able to generate the resolve and reach this stage of the stream-enterer.
Having already attained the small fruits, it is difficult to suddenly turn back.
Like ÅšÄriputra, he is a reflected voice Å›rÄvaka, not a real Å›rÄvaka.
He has already ascended to the Buddha's position and enters the stream to connect with ordinary people.
For this reason, the assembly in this sÅ«tra is different from that of the provisional teachings.
Even if the transformation Buddha is in a place where there is only a pure assembly of bodhisattvas and no small assembly, it is still different from this teaching.
Why is this?
There are some teachings that say:
Those who attain Buddhahood based on this cause do not go through the five stages.
Or the characteristics of the practice and the essence and function of the five stages are different, as already explained above.
According to this example, there is nothing the same.
Since the Dharma is different, the assembly is also completely different.
Moreover, among the assembly in this sÅ«tra, there are ten kinds of the same Dharma that are different from the assembly in other sÅ«tras.

First, the similarity of physical bodies; second, the fundamental wisdom of the Dharma body; third, the wisdom of compassion; fourth, the turning of the Dharma wheel through speech; fifth, the places from which they come; sixth, the methods of accomplishment; seventh, being the same as the causes and effects of the buddhas; eighth, the teacher-disciple relationship with the buddhas; ninth, the perfection of the reward bodies and lands; tenth, the benefit of resolving doubts.

As for the similarity of physical bodies, in the five positions, the bodhisattvas each come from the ten directions. In each direction, the assembly has bodhisattvas from ten buddha-lands' dust-mote-like number of worlds coming. They all have golden-colored bodies, dark-blue eyes and hair. The bodhisattvas in each position have similar physical bodies. The various gods and the eight groups of beings have similar appearances. It is clear that because they attain the same Dharma, their rewards are also the same.

As in the first assembly, there are fifty-five kinds of categories, although they clearly explain the different methods of practice and conversion, the characteristics of practice, the bodies, colors, and Dharma gates are mutually penetrating in the fifty-five categories, one practice becomes many practices, many practices become one practice, one body becomes many bodies, many bodies become one body, because they are similar.
The ten places and ten assemblies before and after are the same.

Second, as for the same fundamental wisdom of the Dharma body, in the ten places and ten assemblies, all the multitudes of beings are the same as the TathÄgata's Dharma nature body, because of the fundamental wisdom.

Even if there are newly studying ordinary beings who enter the assembly, seeing and hearing the Buddha's teachings in an instant they attain entry, all equal to the TathÄgata's Dharma nature body and fundamental wisdom, there is no one who enters the assembly, sees and hears the teachings, who is not the same as the Buddha's body and wisdom.
Five hundred arhats were in the assembly, but they did not see, hear, know, or realize this great assembly and the Dharma gates that were being taught.

Unlike the bodhisattvas, Å›rÄvakas, devas, humans, and the eight classes of beings in the provisional teachings, who gather together to see the Buddha, hear the Dharma, and attain benefits, all of which are completely different.

Third, the sameness of compassion, wisdom, and cognition. The fundamental wisdom of the Dharma body and the wisdom of distinctions have the same essence of compassion. Because understanding and practice are united, they are the one Dharma from beginning to end of the fruition of Buddhahood.

As for the Three Jewels in the Huayan Sutra, the Buddha is the Buddha Jewel, MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« is the Dharma Jewel, and Samantabhadra is the Saá¹ƒgha Jewel. This is because it is the ancient and modern Buddhas' old Dharma.
If united, then all are the same, because the basis is like this, not created, not formed or destroyed.

Fourth, the sameness of the Dharma wheel of speech. As in the sutra, the bodhisattvas in the five positions each come from the ten directions. In each direction there are bodhisattvas as numerous as the dust particles in a buddha land who come to this assembly. The worlds in the ten directions are all like this, gathering like clouds at the same time.
With different mouths but the same voice, the multitudes of the ten directions spoke verses simultaneously, all with the same words and phrases, matching perfectly, without the slightest difference.
This is because their wisdom is the same and their Dharma practices are the same, and the Dharma gates they speak are of one kind throughout the worlds of the ten directions.
It is unlike the multitudes in other sÅ«tras, whose understanding and practices differ, sometimes attaining and sometimes not attaining.
Fifth, the sameness of the places they come from means that the bodhisattvas of these five stages who gather here all come from everywhere in the ten directions.

Moreover, in each of the worlds of the ten directions and within the particles of dust, each bodhisattva dwells together, because they abide in the essence of the Dharma realm, having exhausted the emotions of self and other, this and that, far and near, and because they do not leave a single particle of dust, and also because they originally have no entry.

It is unlike the provisional teachings, where those who have not yet completed three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas and have not yet eliminated their views come to this place and then return to their original lands.
Moreover, it has not yet discussed the realm of a single particle being the perfect Dharma realm.
However, both transformation and change have limits, and it is said that spiritual powers are not the fundamental Dharma.

Sixth, the established Dharma is the same. The practice gates of the ten abodes, ten practices, ten dedications, ten grounds, and five positions of bodhisattvas are the same in the worlds of the ten directions, and the buddhas of the past and present in the worlds of the ten directions are the same in this Dharma. The cause and effect are shown suddenly in a single thought.
The Dharma has no coming and no before or after.

It is not the same as the provisional teachings where the cause precedes and the effect follows. Therefore, only at the end of the ten grounds does one begin to see the nature. Bodhisattvas below the grounds are ordinary beings.
Even if there are those who become buddhas below the grounds, it is attributed to the power of their vows, not to the fundamental Dharma.
It is attributed to the bodhisattvas above the grounds leading the ordinary beings to give rise to superior practices, not discussing the fundamental Dharma that is originally buddha.

This Flower Ornament Sutra directly discusses the gate of the vehicle of the Buddha of fundamental wisdom, not discussing the provisional teachings that set up the gate of the three vehicles over many kalpas.
It directly clarifies that sentient beings' own essence is originally without an agent, and the nature is originally the Dharma realm, the true wisdom of the Buddha, which is taken as the vehicle.

Seventh, as for being the same as the cause and effect of the Buddha, since it is the Dharma body and wisdom body of MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«, the fruition virtues of all Buddhas, and the practices of Samantabhadra, it is originally one Dharma.
All these oceans of multitudes are completely the same as this, and therefore at the initial arousal of the mind, one immediately attains perfect enlightenment.
Those who attain this Dharma in a single instant are not allowed to attain it at a time separate from the instant, because it is not the original Dharma.

If there are people in the Buddha Dharma who see the Buddha attaining enlightenment, making the eons long or short, and giving rise to views based on location, even their faith is not yet accomplished, let alone discussing the cultivation of the path and seeing the path.
Therefore, cultivators should not give rise to such deluded thoughts in accordance with their emotions, falsely claiming to cultivate the path, revolving in birth and death without rest.
This is emotional measurement, not the Buddha Dharma.
Therefore, the assembly in this sutra is all equal to the dharmas of the stage of Buddhahood, and they all attain the dharmas of the stage of Buddhahood.
If there are those who see, hear, understand, and enter, they are all the same as the stage of Buddhahood, because they rely on the fundamental wisdom and dharmas.

The eighth point of sameness between the teacher and disciples is that, like the Indra's net with reflections penetrating each other, the bodhisattvas in this Dharma realm sea of ten assemblies are in the bodies of all Buddhas throughout the Dharma realm, serving the Buddhas everywhere, accomplishing the respectful relationship between teacher and disciple, and being able to be the same as the fruition of Buddhahood, without losing the respect between teacher and disciple.
It is different from the provisional teachings, which have one's own Buddha and other Buddhas, and have coming from those Buddhas and returning to one's own land.

It is different from this teaching, which does not move from the original place, does not perform spiritual powers, and relies on the fundamental Dharma to be always pervading, thus serving the Buddhas and being able to be different.
The ninth point of sameness in the perfect completion of the reward body and lands is because of the true Dharma, which gives rise to faith and practice.

Since the Dharma is always all-pervading, and the body is also all-pervading, the body and lands are all perfect in accordance with the Dharma wisdom. This is because one perfection is all perfections, and the wisdom of non-action is ultimately neither large nor small in size. It is the basis for the Dharma body and wisdom body, and the dependent and principal aspects are also equal.

As for the tenth point of the same benefits for those with doubts, in the first assembly, the fifty-five groups had the same doubts at the same time, and their thoughts and requests were the same. The TathÄgata emitted light to manifest the fruition virtues, and they all benefited at the same time. Each group attained one Dharma, and one person attained the Dharma of all people. The following nine assemblies are all like this.
As for the above ten kinds of the same Dharma in the assembly, they are completely unlike the other teachings.

This is the original wisdom, the original Dharma, the original time, the original place, the original Dharma of the ancient Buddhas, and the ocean of the original assembly of the six stages of practice, filling the empty space and the dust motes, layer upon layer, like this, gathering at one time.

In this sutra, the ocean of the great assembly, from beginning to end, all demonstrates the accomplishment of the five and six stages of the Buddha's cause and effect that the Tathagata rides, and there is not a single person who attains the fruition of the three vehicles. All use this Dharma. From the initial stage of the ten abodes, the essence and function are equal to the Buddha. Relying on the ocean of fundamental wisdom, there is neither increase nor decrease in the nature of the Dharma, and benefiting sentient beings is spontaneous.
The characteristics of the assembly and activities of the ten locations and ten assemblies should be analyzed according to the meaning of the text.

Eighth, clarifying the distinction between principle and phenomena in the Dharma gates that are given. In the teaching of the transformed Buddha's provisional teachings, it is said that sentient beings have Buddha-nature, while insentient beings do not have Buddha-nature, and all grasses and trees cannot attain enlightenment, turn the Dharma wheel, and so forth.

In the Flower Ornament Sutra, it is the teaching that transcends conceptual understanding and reality. It is not like the provisional teachings of the transformed Buddha's school based on the teachings for ordinary beings.

For example, the ten forest bodhisattvas such as the bodhisattva Forest of Merits, the countries from which they come are also called wisdom, and all realms are generally called the essence of wisdom.
Why is this so?
Because there are no sentient beings and no insentient beings.
The reason for this is:
Because there is no dualistic view.
It is the realm of the one true wisdom, with no one who has attained Buddhahood and no one who has not attained Buddhahood.
As for sentient beings and insentient beings, this is spoken from the perspective of karmic dependence.
As for discussing the attainment of Buddhahood, it is not related to karma.
If it is not related to karma, then it is neither sentient nor insentient.
How can one speak of the attainment of Buddhahood or the non-attainment of Buddhahood based on the Dharma that transcends sentient beings?
As for sentient beings and insentient beings, this is included in karma and is not the liberation of the Buddha.
How can one use one's own karmic attachments to make such calculations about the attainment or non-attainment of Buddhahood by sentient beings and insentient beings?

As it is said in the sutra, The characteristics of these empty dharmas are neither arising nor ceasing, neither defiled nor pure. This Dharma abides in the Dharma-position, and the characteristics of the world are always abiding.
Is such a path for sentient beings and insentient beings?

In this way, the great meaning in the Flower Ornament Sutra is originally neither ordinary nor holy, neither sentient nor insentient. The entire true Dharma essence is the realm of a single Buddha's wisdom, and there is no other matter.
Do not use the ordinary person's conceptual mind to falsely make measurements.
If one clings to the mind, one sees sentient beings attain Buddhahood and sees insentient beings not attain Buddhahood. This is one's own karmic grasping.
One who understands in this way will never attain Buddhahood.

As for the statement that the principle pervades insentient beings but is not the same as sentient beings attaining Buddhahood, this is because one has not yet seen the emptiness of dharmas, has not relied on true wisdom, has not yet understood that the various phenomena of the world are originally always abiding, but only sees the phenomena of arising and ceasing that follow conceptual consciousness, and falsely measures, saying that insentient beings only have the principle pervading them.
As for attaining Buddhahood, how could there be a Buddha apart from the principle?

If principle is precisely the Buddha, then within this principle, sentient beings and insentient beings originally have no different characteristics. How could they arise from deluded views as sentient beings and insentient beings?
If the Buddha is insentient, he should not be able to attain Buddhahood.
If there is one who attains great enlightenment, it is not based on these two views. Therefore, the Lotus Sutra unifies the provisional and returns to the real.
The sutra says, The meaning of various natures and characteristics, only I and the Buddhas of the ten directions can understand this matter.
The sravakas, pratyekabuddhas, and irreversible bodhisattvas, these three vehicles of provisional learning, are all unable to comprehend it.
It is extensively explained in that sutra.

In the Huayan Sutra, there are no sentient beings or insentient beings. It is only the realm of wisdom. All mountains, rivers, and trees can manifest the bodies of Buddhas and bodhisattvas and expound the Dharma. The essence of the Buddha can be the same as or different from them, freely and unobstructed.
The Buddha abides and establishes sovereignty and adornment in the world, with distinct and different realms and adornments.

In the marvelous lands and adornments of the Buddha-lands, the Buddha's body appears in each and every realm, within the smallest particle. The Buddha's body is inexhaustible, layer upon layer, in the ocean of Buddha-lands, and the same is true of the pores of the Buddha's body.

The realms are layered upon layers, the Buddha's body is inexhaustible, mutually penetrating each other, able to be the same and different, completely the same and completely different. Pure and defiled lands are unobstructed and unimpeded, not discussing such distinctions between sentient beings and insentient beings.
Therefore, it is said now that the teachings that are given are distinct.
Moreover, in the provisional teachings, practices come first, and the fruition of Buddhahood is after the tenth ground.

In this teaching, the fundamental wisdom of the fruition of Buddhahood comes first, and the discriminating wisdom mutually serves as a support. The characteristics of cause and effect are penetrated all at once, and the past, present, and future are one. When one is accomplished, all are accomplished; when one is destroyed, all are destroyed.
It is not the same as other teachings, where one ground is cultivated in all grounds, because nature, time, practice, and wisdom are the same.
Cultivating concentration and wisdom, using wisdom to contemplate, do not use conceptual understanding.

The ninth point clarifies the difference in attaining the fruit with the three vehicles. As explained in the sutras, for the sake of the Å›rÄvakas, the Dharma of the four truths is expounded, turning away from birth, old age, sickness, and death;
For the sake of the pratyekabuddhas, the twelve links of dependent arising are expounded;

Now, this Flower Ornament Sutra also expounds the Dharma of the four truths, which is not the same as the Dharma of the four truths for the Å›rÄvakas.

As extensively explained in the chapter on the four truths, all are using the four truths to clarify that the root of suffering and accumulation is originally the fundamental wisdom, which is not the same as the three vehicles that have joy and disgust.

Moreover, bodhisattvas on the fifth ground contemplate the ten truths. All buddhas in the worlds of the ten directions expound the Dharma wheel of the four truths, but the sounds they use are different. It is like the methods of governing beings in the world by Confucius and Laozi.

All of them are the Dharma of the four truths, but the depth of understanding by those who receive the teachings is not the same. Some expound the teachings of the twelve divisions, and some speak in the form of spells, but they are all included in the Dharma wheel of the four truths.
Those who are hearers only receive the teachings of ending suffering according to their capacities.
The methods of ending suffering in the Lesser Vehicle are extensively explained in the various texts of the Lesser Vehicle.

To summarize, hearers contemplate the two truths of suffering and its causes, deeply give rise to disgust, and practice the contemplations of impermanence, impurity, white bones, and subtle dust, knowing that the body is empty and tranquil.
In accordance with the empty and tranquil Dharma, wisdom extinguishes and the body perishes. They do not give rise to compassion and wisdom, and this is called cessation.
This place of cessation is called nirvÄá¹‡a.

Even if one arises from concentration, there are still worldly afflictions such as the three poisons. Before entering the path, one cultivates various contemplations to subdue them, like a spell over a poisonous snake.
Moreover, cultivating the realization of the emptiness of persons, one knows that the nature of the mind is extinguished and originally without self.

Because of this principle of the emptiness of persons, the karma of the three poisons is emptied, and compassion and wisdom are not produced. Whether entering or emerging from concentration, there is no cultivation apart from this.
Not apart from this, one is ultimately the same as emptiness. The sudden cessation of the compassionate mind is called the truth of cessation.
Subduing and extinguishing all suffering is called the truth of cessation.
This truth of cessation is called the truth of the path.
As the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra says, It is like a drunken person who, when the alcohol is digested, then awakens.
The realization of dharmas is also like this, attaining the unsurpassed body of a buddha.
In this way, without relying on the wisdom of the buddhas, one cultivates empty samÄdhi one-sidedly.
From this, one knows the faults and turns the mind to the correct path, able to accomplish the body of a buddha.
As the sutra says, Those who have attained permanent cessation are attached to quiescence, so they are urged to cultivate early and should not permanently cease.
Because cultivation gives rise to nirvana, it is not permanent cessation.
This is a reconciliation found in Mahayana sutras.
In the Flower Ornament Sutra, there is no such text.

Like the stream of pratyekabuddhas, they know the twelve links of dependent origination are originally unreal and all empty by nature. They know the body and mind are both without a master, and the nature of body and mind without a master is always selfless. Because of selflessness, ignorance ceases.
Because ignorance ceases, the twelve links of dependent origination cease. They roam freely, following their nature, and awaken on their own.
Unlike shravakas, they do not seek quiescence; unlike bodhisattvas, they lack compassion and wisdom.
Only because they do not seek quiescence are they superior to shravakas;
only because they can uphold the Dharma are they inferior to shravakas.

Therefore, the Å›rÄvakas, having heard the Buddha's teachings on the MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras, are also able to proclaim them, but they have not yet personally realized them, as is criticized in the VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra: Do not speak of the Dharma of true suchness with a mind that arises and ceases.

The bodhisattvas of provisional teachings, who have just turned away from the two vehicles and lesser bodhisattvas, and who are not yet fully endowed with great compassion and wisdom, are like those in the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra and other sÅ«tras.
They only speak of the six perfections, arousing those of lesser faculties to achieve wisdom.

Because their faculties are inferior, they are still afraid of birth and death, and the seven, eight, nine, and ten perfections, etc., are not yet spoken of, because the perfection of skillful means forms their great compassion and because they dwell in birth and death, able to ferry others across.

As the Renwang Jing says, in the outer and inner stages of the ordinary person, one cultivates the six perfections and becomes six kinds of human kings. The four perfections of forbearance and above are all four kinds of wheel-turning kings. Moreover, other sutras gradually transform those of the two vehicles who are partially cultivating and those who are suddenly cultivating, etc., and mature their compassion and wisdom. Although they cultivate the ten perfections, they still cultivate the contemplation of provisional true suchness, contemplating that all phenomena from the beginning have always had an intrinsically real nature that does not change or transform. This destroys the two attachments to emptiness and existence, and accomplishes the Dharma gate of non-arising and non-ceasing, yet still contemplates what appears before the mind.
Below the ninth ground, buddha-nature is not yet clear, because cultivating that provisional wisdom becomes an obstruction. As explained above.

This sutra suddenly reveals the fundamental wisdom for those of superior faculties. From the initial arousal of the mind in the stage of the ten abodes, one is immediately the same as the Buddha in wisdom.
Like Sudhana, who on the summit of Mount Sumeru attained the wisdom-illumination of recollecting all Buddhas, this is its meaning.

Because it relies on fundamental wisdom, there is nothing to cultivate. Since it is originally unobstructed, compassion and wisdom function spontaneously without effort, and all realms are the Dharma realm.
Understanding that the self-nature of dependently arisen dharmas is always true, there is no further cultivation. All thoughts and considerations arise from wisdom.

One only knows to function spontaneously and manifest the form body, speaking the Dharma in response to capacities like an echo. Always dwelling in saá¹ƒsÄra, the Dharma body is eternally quiescent. Although one may pass through many kalpas, the essence does not change with time.
Entering death and being born is not the same as sinking and being born. It is because the Dharma functions spontaneously in response to conditions.
The Dharma should be like this. The nature is free from worry and affliction, and does not dwell in realization or cultivation.
Because the Dharma is like this, the dragon girl and Sudhana both clarify this in general.

This Dharma is difficult to believe in. The three vehicles stand by with folded hands, far pushing this transformation, not something humans can cultivate. Directly speaking of the asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, establishing the kalpas according to one's feelings, how can one believe this timeless wisdom gate?
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says, Being able to believe in this Dharma is extremely difficult, which is exactly the matter.

Even if one diligently practices for many kalpas, there is attainment and seeking, making long and short, making right and wrong, making creation and destruction, abandoning the body and life, how can there be a chance of becoming a Buddha?
How is it that from the initial mind one must enter the Buddha's wisdom realm like this to cultivate and learn? Isn't it saving effort and not wasting work?

For this reason, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and provisional teaching bodhisattvas do not truly understand the four truths, the twelve links of dependent arising, and the wisdom realm of the true suchness Dharma body. They are all expedient practices of Vairocana, heading towards this true ocean of the Flower Ornament Sutra, causing them to return to the fundamental Dharma and act according to their wisdom.

In cultivating the various stages, following the wisdom that is created, the mind that can create does not arise, yet all accomplish the wisdom of all modes, unlike the various teachings where above the stages one must separately cultivate antidotes.

But at the end of the ten faiths and the beginning of the ten abodes, one will naturally understand the realm of the Dharma, the wisdom of the fundamental wisdom realm, where ordinary and sage are not different, and the whole essence is true, not seeing sentient beings and insentient beings, those with nature and those without nature. In this way, the bonds and obstructions allow the Dharma not to arise.

As it is said in the sutra, The Tathagata, having attained perfect enlightenment and appeared in the world, with the wisdom of his own body, universally sees all sentient beings attaining perfect enlightenment. The good and evil emotions are severed, and the nature and characteristics are not different.
Although he delivers sentient beings, there is no one who is delivered. This is called planting the seeds of the characteristics of the Tathagata and all wholesome roots.
